'Quechua' , also known under its endonym 'runa simi' ("people's language"), is a
Native South American language family spoken primarily in the Andes, derived
from a common ancestral language. It is the most widely spoken language family
of the indigenous peoples of the Americas, with a total of probably some 8
million to 10 million speakers. Adelaar 2004, p. 168.
